answers.answerText: A. Deep granular changes at the level of the RPE
B. Disruption of outer retinal layers
C. Disorganization of inner retinal layers
answers.explanation:
The OCT macula demonstrates deep granular changes at the level of the retinal pigmented epithelium (green arrow), disruption of outer retinal layers (yellow arrow), and a thickened choroid (blue arrow). The inner retinal layers seem well organized with no notable pathology.

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
![](/content/media/uveitis-6-4.webp)

The OD fundus autofluorescence image is shown above, demonstrating extensive hyper-autofluorescence throughout the posterior pole. Based on the patient’s provided history, anterior chamber inflammation, and outer retinal abnormalities, what investigations would be most pertinent at this time?

answers.explanation:
The patient’s recent history of genital warts and high risk sexual practices raises concern for a sexually transmitted infection such as syphilis. A comprehensive uveitis work-up for panuveitis should also be performed, including sarcoid and tuberculosis.

​The patient was started on topical prednisolone 1% q2h and atropine TID OU for his cellular activity. A workup was initiated including syphilis and HIV serology. The patient then further disclosed a 2 week history of painless genital ulcers. Given his high risk sexual practices and new chancres, along with placoid chorioretinal lesion, raised the clinical suspicion for ocular syphilis.

​Serology returned one week later:

* RPR reactive
* HIV serology negative

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What treatment should now be initiated based on the above serology results?

answers.answerText: A. Conservative approach with topical steroids and atropine for cellular activity
B. Referral to infectious disease for IV penicillin treatment and lumbar puncture to rule out neurosyphilis
answers.explanation:
It is crucial for the patient to be considered for IV penicillin treatment and investigated for neurosyphilis with a lumbar puncture. Referring to infectious disease is the most appropriate step at this juncture.

Infectious disease was consulted and started IV Penicillin G 4 million units q4h x 14 days. At the 2-week follow-up, his visual acuity was 20/20 OU with resolution of the outer retinal layer disruption and RPE lesions. His optic disc edema had resolved. OD OCT macula at the 2-week follow-up is shown below.

![](/content/media/uveitis-6-5.webp)

answers.answerText: D. 100 mg Doxycyline PO for 7 days

questions.title: Review of OCT
questions.text:
Looking back at the initial OCT, the granular excretions throughout the RPE in the setting of panuveitis and a posterior placoid chorioretinal lesion are pathognomonic for ocular syphilis (green arrow).

title: Case 6
description: 63M presenting with a 1 week history of blurry vision OD
patientPresentation:
**Contributor:** Dr. Safwan Tayeb, MD

A 63-year-old male referred by his optometrist presented with a 1-week history of blurry vision OD. His past medical history was significant for recent genital warts, but negative for systemic inflammatory conditions; past ocular history was unremarkable. The patient smokes 1/2 pack-a-day of cigarettes and disclosed that he is sexually active with multiple partners, both male and female. He does not use protection.
​
His visual acuity was counting fingers OD and 20/25 OS, with normal IOP and extraocular movements. Slit lamp examination found clear corneas but 2+ AC cells OD and 1+ AC cells OS with mild conjunctival injection OU. Colour fundus photos below demonstrate OD optic disc swelling and hyperemia with a deep yellowish placoid chorioretinal lesion over the posterior pole involving the macula.

![](/content/media/uveitis-6-1.webp)

![](/content/media/uveitis-6-2.webp)

​

1. To understand the findings pathognomonic for ocular syphilis.
2. To determine the management for patients suspected of ocular syphilis and posterior placoid chorioretinitis.
